DOC.HEAD: Sihanouk to Vacate U.N. Seat Only Under Certain Conditions
DOC.TEXT: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the exiled Cambodian leader, said Monday that his resistance coalition will vacate its U.N. seat only if the Vietnamese-installed government in Cambodia is dismantled. Austalia's deputy secretary of foreign affairs, Michael Costello, briefed Sihanouk and Chinese leaders separately on Australia's suggestion that the United Nations set up an interim administration in Cambodia so free elections can be held. Costello also met with Premier Li Peng, who said he hoped friendly relations could be restored between Australia and China. Relations have been strained following China's June crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators, which like most Western countries Australia condemned. Sihanouk has said free elections are not possible in Cambodia while the Vietnamese-installed government under Hun Sen remains in office. Hun Sen, however, has demanded the resistance vacate Cambodia's seat in the United Nations to ensure U.N. impartiality while it acts as trustee. Costello's meeting at Sihanouk's residence in Beijing was closed, but the prince later issued a 27-page open letter to Costello, condemning Hun Sen's government and specifying his terms for any U.N. trusteeship. ``I don't accept declaring Cambodia's seat vacant before the simultaneous dismantling of the (resistance) and Hun Sen's `State of Cambodia,' and the replacement of the illegal, pro-Vietnamese administration of Hun Sen with a purely U.N. administration in all villages and provinces,'' the letter said. Vietnam invaded neighboring Cambodia in late 1987 and ousted the ruling Khmer Rouge, who had imposed a reign of terror. However, the United Nations and many governments, including that of the United States, recognize Sihanouk's three-party resistance coalition as the rightful Cambodian government. Hun Sen has said he is willing to allow elections, but has rejected Sihanouk's demand that he first dismantle his government and set up an interim government representing all Cambodian parties, including the Khmer Rouge. The Khmer Rouge are part of Sihanouk's coalition. The issue remained stalemated until Australian Foreign Minister Gareth Evans suggested in November that the United Nations administer Cambodia during elections. Costello has met with officials in Cambodia, Vietnam and Thailand to explain the proposal. The Australian Embassy said Costello's talks would be limited to the problem of Cambodia and would not cover bilateral issues. However, China's official Xinhua News Agency quoted Li Peng as saying that although the two countries differ on some issues, ``We still hope friendly, cooperative relations are restored.'' He said, ``We stand for the forward-looking attitude and hope both sides will join hands for this.'' Australia suspended high-level exchanges with China following the Chinese army attack on pro-democracy protesters in Beijing. The embassy said Costello's visit did not indicate an end of this sanction.
